Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the scent of my mother’s special holiday soup filling the air. My family gathered around, laughing and sharing stories, expecting me to join in the tradition of preparing the meal together, hands bare, feeling the dough and vegetables as generations before us had done. My mother smiled at me, nodding toward the bowl, her eyes full of warmth and expectation. But in my other life, as a housekeeping cleaner, I’d been drilled on the importance of safety and hygiene—always wear gloves, never touch food or surfaces with bare hands after cleaning chemicals. The memory of my supervisor’s stern warnings echoed in my mind. I glanced at my hands, torn between slipping on gloves and risking my family’s disapproval, or going barehanded and betraying everything I’d learned about cleanliness. My heart pounded as I looked from my family’s eager faces to the gloves tucked in my bag, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in on me.
